title: Geometry
description: Covers 12-15% of the ACT. Master angles, lines, triangles (including Pythagorean theorem and special right triangles), polygons, circles, area/volume/surface area, coordinate geometry, right triangle trig, and congruence/similarity. The ACT provides NO formula sheet — memorization is essential.
goals: Apply angle relationships: complementary, supplementary, vertical, transversal
Solve triangle problems using angle sum, Pythagorean theorem, and special triangles
Calculate area, perimeter, circumference, and volume using memorized formulas
Apply distance, midpoint, and circle equations in the coordinate plane
Use SOH-CAH-TOA to solve right triangle problems
Apply similarity ratios and scale factor relationships
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release: concept-intro → I Do → We Do → You Do → mastery-check
AI uses scaffold array as scope and worked-example bank
Formula memorization drills integrated into every section
Emphasis on diagram drawing and labeling as a problem-solving tool
Special right triangles and Pythagorean triples highlighted as high-frequency ACT content

scaffold.title: Angles, Lines & Triangles
scaffold.content: Geometry accounts for 12-15% of the ACT, and angle/triangle questions are the foundation. The ACT loves parallel lines with transversals, triangle angle sums, and exterior angle problems.
keyPoints: Complementary angles sum to 90°. Supplementary angles sum to 180°.
Vertical angles are equal (formed by two intersecting lines).
Parallel lines + transversal: corresponding angles equal, alternate interior angles equal, co-interior angles sum to 180°.
Triangle angle sum: all three angles add to 180°.
Exterior angle theorem: exterior angle = sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles.
Triangle inequality: any side must be less than the sum of the other two.
Pythagorean theorem: a² + b² = c² (right triangles only, c is hypotenuse).
Common Pythagorean triples: 3-4-5, 5-12-13, 8-15-17, 7-24-25 (and their multiples).
Special right triangles: 45-45-90 → x : x : x√2. 30-60-90 → x : x√3 : 2x.

examples.problem:
Two parallel lines are cut by a transversal. One of the angles formed is 65°. What is the measure of its co-interior (same-side interior) angle?
(A) 25°  (B) 65°  (C) 90°  (D) 115°  (E) 125°
examples.solution:
Co-interior angles are supplementary (sum to 180°).
180° − 65° = 115°
Answer: (D) 115°

examples.problem:
In a right triangle, the legs are 6 and 8. What is the hypotenuse?
(A) 10  (B) 12  (C) 14  (D) √100  (E) Both A and D
examples.solution:
Recognize the 3-4-5 triple scaled by 2: 6-8-10.
Or calculate: c² = 6² + 8² = 36 + 64 = 100 → c = 10.
Answer: (E) Both A and D (10 = √100).

ACT Tip: Always check for Pythagorean triples before calculating.

examples.problem:
One leg of a 30-60-90 triangle is 5 (the shortest leg). What is the hypotenuse?
(A) 5√2  (B) 5√3  (C) 10  (D) 10√3  (E) 15
examples.solution:
In a 30-60-90 triangle: x : x√3 : 2x.
Shortest leg (opposite 30°) = x = 5.
Hypotenuse = 2x = 10.
Answer: (C) 10

The longer leg = 5√3 ≈ 8.66.

scaffold.title: Polygons, Circles, Area & Volume
scaffold.content: These are the formulas you MUST have memorized for the ACT. There is no formula sheet provided. Circle and area/volume questions appear on every single ACT.
keyPoints: Interior angle sum of n-gon: (n−2) × 180°. Each angle of regular n-gon: (n−2) × 180° / n.
Circle: circumference = 2πr = πd. Area = πr².
Arc length = (central angle / 360°) × 2πr.
Sector area = (central angle / 360°) × πr².
Triangle: A = (1/2)bh. Rectangle: A = lw. Parallelogram: A = bh.
Trapezoid: A = (1/2)(b₁ + b₂)h.
Rectangular prism: V = lwh. Cylinder: V = πr²h.
Cone: V = (1/3)πr²h. Sphere: V = (4/3)πr³. SA = 4πr².
Pyramid: V = (1/3)Bh where B = base area.

examples.problem:
What is the area of a circle with diameter 10?
(A) 10π  (B) 20π  (C) 25π  (D) 50π  (E) 100π
examples.solution:
Diameter = 10, so radius = 5.
A = πr² = π(5²) = 25π
Answer: (C) 25π

Trap: (E) 100π uses the diameter instead of the radius.

(A) 24π  (B) 48π  (C) 72π  (D) 192π  (E) 216π

scaffold.title: Coordinate Geometry & Right Triangle Trig
scaffold.content: Coordinate geometry bridges algebra and geometry. The ACT tests distance, midpoint, slope, and circle equations in the coordinate plane. Right triangle trig (SOH-CAH-TOA) is also heavily tested.
keyPoints: Distance: d = √[(x₂−x₁)² + (y₂−y₁)²]
Midpoint: M = ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2)
Circle: (x−h)² + (y−k)² = r². Center (h,k), radius r.
To convert general form to standard: complete the square for x and y.
SOH-CAH-TOA for right triangles: sin = opp/hyp, cos = adj/hyp, tan = opp/adj.
Pythagorean triples appear in coordinate geometry: distance between (0,0) and (3,4) is 5.
Similar triangles: corresponding sides proportional, corresponding angles equal.

examples.problem:
What is the distance between (−1, 3) and (5, −5)?
(A) 6  (B) 8  (C) 10  (D) 14  (E) √52

What are the center and radius of the circle x² + y² − 6x + 4y − 12 = 0?
(A) Center (3, −2), r = 5  (B) Center (−3, 2), r = 5  (C) Center (3, −2), r = 25  (D) Center (6, −4), r = 12  (E) Center (3, −2), r = √12
examples.solution:
Complete the square:
(x² − 6x + 9) + (y² + 4y + 4) = 12 + 9 + 4
(x − 3)² + (y + 2)² = 25
Center: (3, −2), radius = √25 = 5
Answer: (A) Center (3, −2), r = 5

examples.problem:
A 20-foot ladder leans against a wall making a 65° angle with the ground. How high up the wall does the ladder reach?
(A) 20 sin 65°  (B) 20 cos 65°  (C) 20 tan 65°  (D) 20/sin 65°  (E) 20/cos 65°
examples.solution:
The ladder is the hypotenuse (20 ft). The wall height is opposite the 65° angle.
sin 65° = opposite/hypotenuse = height/20
height = 20 sin 65°
Answer: (A) 20 sin 65°

ACT Tip: Draw the triangle and label the sides relative to the given angle.

problems.problem:
What is the midpoint of the segment from (2, −3) to (8, 7)?
(A) (5, 2)  (B) (3, 5)  (C) (10, 4)  (D) (6, 4)  (E) (5, 5)

A tree casts a 15-foot shadow when the angle of elevation of the sun is 40°. How tall is the tree?
(A) 15 sin 40°  (B) 15 cos 40°  (C) 15 tan 40°  (D) 15/tan 40°  (E) 15/sin 40°
hints: The shadow is adjacent to the 40° angle
The tree height is opposite. tan 40° = height/15

problems.problem:
Two similar triangles have corresponding sides in the ratio 3:5. If the smaller triangle has area 27 cm², what is the area of the larger?
(A) 45  (B) 75  (C) 108  (D) 135  (E) 225
hints: Area scales by the square of the linear scale factor

problems.problem:
A circle has equation (x + 1)² + (y − 4)² = 36. What is the diameter?
(A) 6  (B) 12  (C) 18  (D) 36  (E) 72

An exterior angle of a triangle is 130°. If one of the non-adjacent interior angles is 50°, what is the other non-adjacent interior angle?
(A) 50°  (B) 60°  (C) 70°  (D) 80°  (E) 130°
problems.answer: (D) 80°. Exterior angle = sum of remote interior angles. 130° = 50° + x → x = 80°.
